data.title: In each row of the table select the stronger
data.meta_description: [Solved] In each row of the table select the stronger acid or stronger base as instructed
data.text:
Acidity and Basicity Definition A Bronsted-Lowry acid and base are a proton donor andproton acceptor respectively NH3H N HH Hacid base OH 3OH conjugateacidconjugate base Ka = NH3 H3 O+ NH4 + H CH3H NH2 H OHHF5035163Across a rowHF3H ClHBrHI -8-9-10 Down a column OHOH 16OOHOOHOOHO OH FFFF F F 47271302 Laboratory Exercise 3 Acid and Base Separation Through Extraction pKa = pKa = 10 pKa = 2 The dissociative equilibrium constant of an acid in H2O is defined as Ka where pKa= - log10Ka A stronger acid exhibits a greater degree of dissociation to its conjugate base which is reflected in a larger Ka and smaller pKa When comparing relative acidities of neutral acids there are several factors that contribute to stabilization of the conjugate base (ie anion) if the conjugate base is more stablized the proton should be removed more readilyIn order of decreasing importance the following factors influence the pKa of a molecule Atomic CharacteristicsWhen comparing acids whose atoms to which the protons are bonded are in the same row of the periodic table electronegativity dominates a more electronegative atom yields a stronger acid When comparing acids whose atoms to which the protons are bonded exist in the same column of the periodic table than size dominates as the negative charge of the anionic conjugate base is better delocalized (C

Answered step-by-step

1 answer

Read each question carefully select the most accurate answer from the given options and briefly justify your choice using your knowledge on pH and buffers Why is water considered amphoteric 2 points It cannot act as an acid or a base It can act both as an acid and a base It can act as a base only It can act as an acid only This is a required question In the context of acids and bases what is a conjugate base 2 points A species formed by the addition of a proton to a base A species formed by the removal of a proton from an acid The acid formed when a base gains a proton The base formed when an acid loses a proton This is a required question What is the pH of a solution with a hydrogen ion concentration of 1x10-4 M 2 points -4 4 10 -10 Which of the following is NOT a property of a buffer solution 2 points It can resist changes in pH when small amounts of an acid or a base are added It drastically changes pH when large amounts of an acid or a base are added It can maintain a relatively constant pH It contains significant amounts of a weak acid and its conjugate base According to the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation if the concentration of a weak acid and its conjugate base are equal what would be the pH of the solution 2 points 1 Equal to the pKa of the acid 7 14 This is a required question What is a conjugate acid 2 points The acid formed when a base gains a proton A species formed by the addition of a proton to a base A species formed by the removal of a proton from an acid The base formed when an acid loses a protonThe base formed when an acid loses a proton A base buffer primarily contains which of the following 2 points Large amounts of a weak acid and its conjugate base The acid formed when a base gains a proton Large amounts of a weak base and its conjugate acid It completely removes acid or base from a solution A base buffer primarily contains which of the following 2 points It completely removes acid or base from a solution Large amounts of a weak acid and its conjugate base Large amounts of a weak base and its conjugate acid The acid formed when a base gains a proton A base buffer primarily contains which of the following 2 points It completely removes acid or base from a solution 70 476 Large amounts of a weak base and its conjugate acid This is a required question If the pOH of a solution is 3 what is the pH of the solution 2 points 7 3 14 11
